The last thing Whitehall needs is a Chief Financial Officer 

Updated at 5.26pm GMT

3.33pm GMT

Mark Carney appearing at House of Lords committee

Heads-up. Bank of England governor Mark Carney is about to appear before the House of Lords Economic Affairs Committee to give his annual testimony.

It will be streamed live here, from 3.35pm.

Here's the issues which the committee plans to raise with the governor:

  • What is his assessment of the UK’s medium term economic prospects?
  • Whether the realities of serving as Governor of the Bank of England have matched his expectations and what lessons he is applying that he learnt from his time as Governor of the Bank of Canada.
  • How he expects his introduction of forward guidance on monetary policy (announcing that interest rates would not change while unemployment remains above 7%) to influence economic behaviour?
  • Is there a risk that using unemployment as the signal to raise interest rates could be too late for effective control of inflation?
  • Is there a conflict between the Bank’s scrapping of the Funding for Lending scheme which supported mortgage lending and the expansion of the government’s Help to Buy scheme?
  • Would the Bank’s financial stability objective be easier to meet if there was a full separation between retail and investment banking?
  • Should bankers be subject to full professional standards in the same way as doctors and lawyers?
  • What is his view on Scottish Government’s aim set out in its White Paper to retain sterling as the currency of an independent Scotland?

Updated at 3.42pm GMT

3.16pm GMT

The Eurogroup of finance ministers has just confirmed that Greece has done enough to receive its next aid tranche, worth €1bn in total.

In a statement, president Jeroen Dijsselbloem (who is also Dutch finance minister) said:

I note with satisfaction that Greece has achieved the four milestones agreed with the Troika institutions in the context of the third review of its economic adjustment programme.

Before adding:

I am confident that the Greek authorities will swiftly conclude their discussions with the Troika institutions in order to allow for a completion of the ongoing review of the country’s economic adjustment programme.

And those milestones?

  • First, Greece has placed over 12 500 public employees in the mobility scheme as part of the strategy to make the public administration more efficient.
  • Second, Greece has taken adequate measures to significantly restructure or liquidate three state-owned companies which were intended for privatisation.
  • Third, a Code of Lawyers was adopted to enhance the functioning of this regulated profession.
  • Finally, Greece took the required steps to improve the financial situation of the two main water companies, by clearing government arrears, in order to facilitate their privatisation.

But as our Helena Smith flagged up at 2.38pm, there are still several outstanding issues - including over a freeze on home repossessions.

3.10pm GMT

Speaking of Greece.... public faith in the Athens political classes won't be improved by the news that a former transport minister is due to appear before prosecutors after being stopped by traffic police.

According to local media, Michalis Liapis was apprehended on suspicion of driving with fake number plates, no licence, and no insurance. Kathimerini reports that Liapis is already €500 lighter, and still needs to explain the alleged false plates to a court.

2.50pm GMT

Just flagging up a few stories by my colleagues this morning:

GlaxoSmithKline to stop paying doctors to promote products

Drug maker GlaxoSmithKline will no longer pay doctors to promote its products as it attempts to modernise at a difficult time for the company.

The British pharmaceutical company will also stop paying bonuses to its sales staff based on the number of prescriptions written by doctors and will no longer pay doctors and medical professionals to attend conferences.

Bob Diamond raises £200m to invest in African banks

Bob Diamond, ousted as boss of Barclays last year following the Libor-rigging scandal, has staged a dramatic return by raising £200m in a stock market listed company targeting the acquisition of financial services companies in Africa.

The American banker – often criticised for the size of his pay cheques – has become a non-executive director of a cash shell which has ambitious plans to buy into fast-growing African banks.

Great British Bake Off boosts Dixons

Dixons said the popularity of the BBC television series The Great British Bake Off was boosting sales of kitchen gadgets in the run-up toChristmas but warned of a challenging period ahead.

The chief executive, Sebastian James, said all kinds of baking-related products were flying off the shelves, with Kitchenaid mixers in "garish colours" proving particularly popular.

2.38pm GMT

Greek central bank raises forecasts,but sees political trouble ahead

Over in Greece, central Bank governor Giorgos Provopoulos has presented his annual report this morning .

As our correspondent Helena Smith reports, it’s a mix of good and bad news.

 Greece’s central bank governor rarely minces his words and today was no exception.

Presenting the bank’s monetary policy program to parliament, days before the 300-seat House goes into recess over Christmas, Giorgos Provopoulos broke the good news first: after six years mired in recession, the debt-stricken country was about to turn the corner.

The economy would contract by 4.0% in 2013 and not by 4.6% as originally forecast, and will also achieve a primary budget surplus.

But.....

Breaking the bad news, the governor also sounded the alarm by warning that Greece’s economic recovery was fragile and in danger of being derailed by mounting political uncertainty.

In an atmosphere that has become increasingly electric politically, double elections next year for the European Parliament and regional authorities (which both take place in May) posed a particular danger, he said.

“[They] represent a justifiable cause for concern that political tensions will rise and polarization become more acute,” he said urging consensus among the country’s fractious political elite.

Provopoulos’ warning came as senior government officials admitted that relations with Greece’s “troika” of creditors were especially strained even if consensus has been reached on revamping Greece’s ailing defence industries.

That breakthrough was highlighted this afternoon when the eurozone's working group released €1bn of loans to Athens shortly before eurozone finance ministers begin talks in Brussels.

But the long negotiations between Greece and the Troika are still not over, Helena adds:

Mission chiefs representing the EU, ECB and IMF left Athens today after failing to bridge differences over a number of issues not least the potentially explosive matter of banks repossessing homes to claim bad debts.

Finance ministry sources are saying they won’t be back until January “and right now we have no idea when."

2.26pm GMT

European finance minister take another swing at banking rules

Eurozone finance ministers will be gathering in Brussels tonight for another meeting of the eurogroup, and it could be a long haul.

Top of the agenda -- finalising a deal on the outstanding points around European banking union in time for a leaders' Summit meeting later this week.

EU officials have just tweeted that there won't be a press conference tonight....

Tomorrow, finance ministers from the rest of the EU join their euro colleagues for a full European Council meeting. And there are still plenty of hurdles over the details of banking union to clear up.

The FT's Peter Spiegel has uploaded the 19-page discussion note circulated ahead of the meeting, which shows that finance ministers are still divided over these key issues:

Who takes the decision to shut a failing European bank? (is the current plan too complicated? Who's really in charge?)

The legal framework behind the new rescue fund that would recapitalise failed banks (Germany wants it tied into a new treaty, which takes time)

(and crucially) Is there enough money in the pot to actually save Europe's banks in a crisis? Only, it seems, if the €500bn European Stability Mechanism (set up to fund sovereign bailouts) is used, and Germany opposes that (which is why the 'backstop problem' might not be on the agenda at all).

1.46pm GMT

US inflation data released

US inflation data is out, and it's lower than expected.

The cost of living in America was unchanged month-on-month in November, with falling gasoline prices cancelling out higher food and housing costs. 

On an annual basis, the US Consumer Prices Index rose 1.2%, up from 1.0% in October (but still almost a whole percentage point below Britain's inflation rate). 

Economists had expected prices to rise 0.1% month-on-month, and 1.3% annually.

So, nothing to shock the Federal Reserve's monetary policy committee (the FOMC) as it starts its two-day meeting. We find out tomorrow if the Fed has taken the plunge to ease back on its bond-buying stimulus programme, which is currently pumping $85bn of new money into the US system each month.

Kit Juckes of Société Générale reckons the Fed should start winding back the programme soon:

That bond buying is what is keeping equities up and the dollar down. The latter may suit the US economy; the former is simply storing up trouble for later. That's why tapering would be a good idea this week.

Updated at 1.46pm GMT

1.16pm GMT

Two interesting charts to flag up about the UK housing market.

1) Comprehensive lending data released this morning shows that one in every four pounds of mortgage loans are held against property in London postcodes.

The postcode with the most mortgage debt is SW11 6 in South London (part of Wandsworth), followed by E14 9 (parts of of Tower Hamlets, including Canary Wharf and the Isle of Dogs).

There is £227bn worth of home loans outstanding in the capital, compared to just £26bn in the whole of Wales.

2) While UK house prices are at a new record high, that doesn't account for inflation. This chart, via Sky News's Ed Conway, shows how the average price in real terms is around 17% off the 2007 peak. London prices are close to new highs.

12.56pm GMT

City economists have been scribbling out their forecasts for UK inflation in 2014, after today's data (which showed the cost of living rising by 0.1 percentage point less than expected in November).

Updated at 12.58pm GMT

12.48pm GMT

Here's Reuters' story about Tom Hayes' court appearance this morning:

Libor rate-rigging scandal trader pleads not guilty

Updated at 1.32pm GMT

12.44pm GMT

Rob Harbron, economist at the CEBR, has commented on this morning's drop in UK inflation to a four-year low of 2.1%:

The largest contributor to this downward movement came from the food and non-alcoholic drinks sector, where annual price increases slowed to 2.8% - the smallest rise since September 2012. Low crop yields caused by poor weather conditions in 2012 had pushed up the prices of some fresh produce in November last year, but this effect has since fallen out.

A second key factor easing pressure on the headline rate was the cost of home utilities. Annual price inflation on electricity and gas fell to 6.7% and 6.3% respectively, each down roughly two percentage points from October to reach their lowest rates since early 2013. This is the result of the timings of tariff hikes – none of the recently announced price increases had taken place by November, whereas the cost of home utilities started to push up CPI in the same month last year.

This further improvement of the inflationary environment will help to reduce the squeeze on UK household spending power, a factor that is likely to help support consumer confidence. A robust expansion of the UK economy is expected for Q4 2013, boosted in part by consumer spending.

However, despite today’s good news for UK households, the gap between inflation and wage growth remains substantial. Total average wages rose year on year by just 0.8% in the three months to September 2013, and inflation is not expected to fall further as the effects of utility price hikes start to feed in. The outlook for the economy may be brightening, but the benefits brought by growth will take longer to reach the average household.

Updated at 2.37pm GMT

12.13pm GMT

Not guilty pleas in Libor trial

Over at Southwark Crown Court, three men have pleaded not guilty to charges related to allegations of attempts to rig the Libor benchmark interest rates.

Tom Hayes, a former UBS and Citigroup trader, and two former RP Martin brokers Terry Farr and James Gilmour, are the first people to appear in court over claims that attempts were made to manipulate Libor over several years.

All three deny the charges, brought by the UK's Serious Fraud Office. The trial may not begin for over a year.

Here's Press Association's early take:

Former trader Tom Hayes today pleaded not guilty to eight charges in relation to allegations of Libor rate rigging.

Hayes entered the pleas during a hearing at Southwark Crown Court. His trial will not take place until 2015.

Charges of conspiracy to defraud cover a period from 2006 to 2010.

Libor is the term for benchmark rates that underpin hundreds of trillions of dollars of contracts from mortgages to corporate lending.

Two other defendants, Terry Farr and James Gilmour, denied separate charges. 

The WSJ has more details from the 'packed' courtroom: Three Charged in Libor Plead Not Guilty

11.33am GMT

The rise in UK house prices to record levels (see 9.39am onwards) comes at a time when mortgage approvals are running at half their pre-crisis peak.

That worries Josh Raymond of City Index, who tweets:

11.32am GMT

Duncan Weldon, the TUC's senior economist, sums up the situation:

11.13am GMT

UK inflation may rise again as this winter's energy price rises hit households, warns David Kern, chief economist at the British Chambers of Commerce (as explained earlier, those tariff increases don't appear in November's inflation data).

Kern says:

The small fall in inflation will help ease the pressure felt by businesses and consumers at a time when earnings are still rising by less than 1%.

It will also make good reading for the Bank of England's monetary policy committee as it tries to keep interest rates at a historic low for an extended period, and suggests that in the short term it is possible to combine low inflation with low interest rates.

However inflation remains a concern for many businesses, and imminent energy rises may add to inflationary pressures in the months ahead. 

10.55am GMT

UK inflation also remains higher than in the euro area. New data this morning has confirmed that eurozone prices rose by just 0.9% year-on-year in November.

That's a rise from October's inflation rate of 0.7%, which had prompted fears that the eurozone was sliding into deflation (as has already happened in Greece).

Howard Archer, economist at IHS Global Insight, points out that real wages are falling in some parts of the eurozone, as in the UK:

For consumers, the news is mixed. On the one hand, very low consumer price inflation is good for their purchasing power.

However, this is countered by very weak wage growth.

Indeed, given that overall Eurozone annual wage growth of 1.3% in the third quarter was lifted by German and French wages both rising by 1.7%, it is evident that workers in many countries are facing falling or essentially flat real incomes which clearly limits the ability of consumers to play a major role in helping recoveries to develop.

10.31am GMT

Labour: Cost of living crisis continues

The Labour party has also welcomed the drop in UK inflation, before pointing out that it means real wages in the UK are still shrinking.

Catherine McKinnell MP, Labour's Shadow Economic Secretary to the Treasury, said:

This small fall in the inflation rate is welcome, but with prices still rising much faster than wages the cost-of-living crisis continues. Families and pensioners are still set to face inflation-busting hikes in energy prices this winter, which the ONS says are not in today's figures.

After three damaging years of flatlining, working people are on average £1600 a year worse off. But the Autumn Statement failed to set out a plan to tackle the cost-of-living crisis and earn our way to higher living standards for the many and not just a few.

Labour would freeze energy bills until 2017 while we reform the energy market, make work pay by expanding free childcare for working parents and get at least 200,000 homes built a year by 2020.

By opposing all these measures and giving a huge tax cut to people earning over £150,000 David Cameron has shown he only stands up for a privileged few.

10.23am GMT

UK Treasury welcomes drop in inflation

News that the cost of living is rising at its lowest rate in four years has been hailed by the Treasury as proof that the economy is on the right track:

Here's the official comment:

Inflation has fallen to its lowest level in four years. The government’s long term economic plan is working. All parts of the economy are growing, the deficit is falling and jobs are being created. But the job is not done and the government will go on taking the tough decisions needed to create a sustainable recovery for all.

Times remain tough for many people so wherever possible we have found the money to freeze fuel duty, freeze council tax and take 2.7 million people out of tax by increasing the tax free personal allowance.

It's worth remembering, though, that Britain's easing inflation rate is partly due to global energy prices being stable recently. The cost of a barrel of oil almost doubled between 2009 and 2011 (from $50 to $100), driving up the cost of living (as that previous chart made clear).

10.12am GMT

Inflation: the key charts

Here's two ONS graphs - one showing how the UK inflation rate has finally fallen close to the official target of 2%, for the first time in four years:

While the other explains which factors pushed the inflation rate up, and which pulled it down.

Updated at 10.22am GMT

10.10am GMT

Inflation: 'recreation and culture' costs up

Computer gaming got costlier in November, according to the Office for National Statistics.

It reports that items in its 'recreation & culture' section rose by 0.4% between October and November this year, compared with a negligible change between the same two months in 2012:

The upward contribution came from games, toys & hobbies (particularly computer games) and data processing equipment.

Two new computer game consoles launched in the UK last month, the XBox One and the PlayStation 4, compete with a roster of fresh games to play on 'em.

9.59am GMT

Inflation: Food and hotel easing

The ONS also reported that UK food and non-alcoholic beverage prices also rose at a slower pace than a year ago:

Prices, overall, were little changed between October and November 2013 compared with a rise of 1.1% between the same two months a year ago.

The main downward contributions came from fruit, where prices rose by less than a year ago, and vegetables, where prices fell this year but rose a year ago. For some fresh produce, there were reports of low yields in 2012 caused by poor weather conditions. There was also a small downward effect from bread & cereals where prices fell slightly this year but rose a year ago.

And hotel and restaurant costs also rose at a lower rate between October and November than a year ago:

The downward effect came from both accommodation services, particularly from hotel overnight stays, and catering services.

9.56am GMT

Energy bill price rises not priced in (yet)

The drop in UK inflation last month was partly because recent energy price rises have yet to feed into the calculations.

The ONS warned:

Prices, overall, were little changed between October and November 2013 compared with a rise of 0.6% between the same two months a year ago.

The effect came almost entirely from gas and electricity and relates to the timing of price rises: none of the recently announced rises has entered the index this month whereas last winter’s increases began to affect the index in November 2012.

That suggests the inflation rate will pick up again once the tariff increase from the likes of British Gas and nPower hit our doormats.

9.47am GMT

At 2.1%, UK inflation is still running at more than double the average pay rise. 

Average earnings are up by just 0.8% over the last year (we'll get new data on that tomorrow). So real wages continue to fall, and the living standards squeeze continues.

9.42am GMT

The fall in UK inflation will be welcomed by the Bank of England, as it means less pressure to consider tightening monetary policy (it's official policy is to maintain rates at their record low of 0.5% until the jobless rate has fallen).

9.39am GMT

House prices up 5.5% in UK,. 12% in London

House prices in London have led the way over the last year, according to the ONS, rising by an average of 12% in the 12 months to October. That's more than double the national average rise of 5.5%, which takes the average price to a new record high.

Updated at 9.45am GMT

9.35am GMT

But house prices are up! The Office for National Statistics reports that house prices across the UK rose by 5.5% in the 12 months to October, which is the fastest increase since September 2010 (according to ONS data).

9.32am GMT

UK inflation falls

JUST IN: UK inflation has fallen to a four-year low.

The Consumer prices index rose by 2.1% in November, down from 2.2% the previous month, which is the smallest increase since November 2009.

More to follow:

9.23am GMT

Moscovici hopes for better luck with Merkel's third government

France's finance minister, Pierre Moscovici, has welcomed the formation of Angela Merkel's new coalition, and criticised her previous administration for being too focused on austerity.

With the French economy at risk of sliding into recession, Moscovici hopes that the presence of the SPD around the cabinet table will help German to focus more on eurozone growth.

Speaking on France 2 TV shortly before Merkel was voted back in, Moscovici declared:

It's true that the previous administration was far too focused on austerity....

Now there is a Social Democratic partner ... I think we'll have a Germany that is more growth-oriented.

Through the coalition discussions, the SPD persuaded Merkel to agree to the introduction of a national minimum wage (rather than individual industries hammering out deals). That could boost the spending power of poorer Germans.

But the CDU baulked at the idea of raising taxes to fund additional government spending on infrastructure projects.

Updated at 9.24am GMT

9.16am GMT

The formalities are over - Angela Merkel is officially Germany's leader again.

9.06am GMT

Over in Germany, Angela Merkel will be formally voted in as German chancellor this morning, for the third time, as the new coalition between her CDU/CSU party and the Social Democrats gets down to business.

Although the CDU-SPD coalition is new, there's no change at the top of one key department. Wolfgang Schäuble remains as finance minister, which suggests little change in Germany's focus on fiscal consolidation as the cure to eurozone woes.

Our economics correspondent, Phillip Inman, sees a lost opportunity.

For Spain, Italy, Greece and Portugal, his reappointment is a nightmare: they have massive debts to pay, and according to the Schäuble doctrine those debts must be honoured.

For Europe's low-skilled, poorly paid workers and the young, it is a message that austerity must go on while the benefits of recovery, in the form of corporate profits and tax receipts, are transferred to the old and wealthy.

8.47am GMT

Look who's back! Bob Diamond has returned to the City this morning, almost 18 months after quitting as Barclays CEO over the Libor scandal.

Diamond's new shell company, Atlas Mara, has raised £200m by listing on the London Stock Exchange. It will use the money to invest in African banks.

Diamond founded Atlas Mara with billionaire entrepreneur Ashish Thakkar, chief executive of Mara Group.

Reuters has more details:

The proceeds from the initial public offering included a $20 million investment by its founders.

The vehicle will be managed by Atlas Merchant Capital, the merchant bank Diamond has set up in New York with a view to expand into sub-Saharah African banks and financial services.

8.29am GMT

Inflation to show real wages still shrinking

Economists and traders will be glued to their terminals in an hour's time when the latest UK inflation data, for November, flashes up.

City analysts reckon there will be no change in the rising cost of living, with the Consumer Prices Index expected to rise by 2.2%, matching October.

As economics reporter Katie Allen explains, that would mean real wages were still shrinking .

The consumer price index measure of inflation is expected to hold at 2.2% in November according to the consensus forecast in a Reuters poll. But some economists see the rate dropping to 2% while others have pencilled in a rise to 2.5%.

Inflation has been above average annual earnings growth for several years now and the latest official figures put pay growth at 0.8%.

8.24am GMT

Key event

The big transport (and political) news in Britain today is that a government report into airport congestion has recommended building new runways at either Heathrow or Gatwick.

My colleague Andy Sparrow is covering the report live here: Heathrow expansion - Airports Commission publishes interim report: Politics live blog

And our transport correspondent Gwyn Topham has the story:

A new battle looms over a Heathrow third runway after the Airports Commission said additional capacity was needed in the south-east of England, with extra runways at London's biggest airport foremost among the options it will study before issuing its final recommendation, along with an extra runway at Gatwick.

The government-appointed independent commission, led by Sir Howard Davies has issued a shortlist of three options for building new runways in the south-east in its interim report.

The options set out by Davies are: a third runway to the north of Heathrow, a second proposal for Heathrow expansion put forward by the Heathrow Hub group, and a new second runway to the south of Gatwick.

Heathrow and Gatwick airports shortlisted for new runways

So, no joy for 'Boris Island' -- instead, the prospect of even more flights over the capital, including its more salubrious 'burbs.

8.18am GMT

Once you've splashed out on a new car, of course, you've got to insure the thing. And Britain's Competition Commission is concerned that motorists may be being shunted in the pocket.

After conducting a review of the £11bn private motor insurance market, the CC reckons that the market "is not working well for motorists".

It reckons that insurers of the driver who wasn't at fault in an accident are running up unnecessary charges (repairs, replacement cars and the like), meaning the 'at fault' driver's insurers pick up the bill. Ultimately, everyone suffers, with up to £200m of extra costs needing to be spread across premiums.

As Alasdair Smith of the CC explains:

There is insufficient incentive for insurers to keep costs down even though they are themselves on the receiving end of the problem.

More here: Car insurance too high, says Competition Commission

8.07am GMT

Signs of recovery in EU car market

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of events across the economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and business.

Some mildly encouraging news to start the day - European car sales rose last month, for the third month in a row.

ACEA, the industry body, reported that sales across the EU in November were 1.2% higher than the previous year -- meaning a hat-trick of annual gains (see chart above) as the battered auto sector steers towards Christmas.

But the bulk of the increase was due to continued strong demand in the UK (where many cars appear to be being snapped up on credit ), and Spain (where the government has offered a series of 'cash-for-bangers' schemes to encourage demand).

France, teetering on the edge of recession, continued to see its car market shrink, though.

As ACEA explains:

In November, the UK (+7.0%) and Spanish (+15.1%) markets contributed to the overall 1.2% upturn. Demand in Germany (-2.0%), France (-4.0%) and Italy (-4.5%) was lower than in the same month last year.

In total, the EU* counted 938,021 new registrations. In absolute figures, this represents the third lowest level recorded to date** for a month of November.

It's been a tough year for the sector, with manufacturers selling 2.7% fewer cars so far than in 2012. Much of 2013 must look like a write-off to car makers -- they must hope that 2014 will be better.

Some manufacturers struggled rather more than others. Fiat reported a 5.8% drop in sales, while GM registrations are down 2.9% and Peugeot Citroen saw sales down 1.2%. Renault, though, posted an 8.9% surge during the month, and Toyota were up 6.9%.

Lots more to follow... including the latest UK inflation reading at 9.30am, a Eurogroup meeting of finance ministers in Brussels, and drugs maker GSK announcing a clampdown on its payments model....

fields.bodyText: As the Bank of England's carol service gets into full swing, let's round up the key points. Bank of England governor Mark Carney has told the House of Lords that Britain's economy is recovering, but warned that the weak state of the eurozone could hold it back. In his first appearance at the Lords' Economics Committee, Carney said that the recovery had "finally taken hold", but it's too early to consider tightening monetary policy (here's his opening statement). More to follow: France's finance minister, Pierre Moscovici, has welcomed the formation of Angela Merkel's new coalition, and criticised her previous administration for being too focused on austerity. With the French economy at risk of sliding into recession, Moscovici hopes that the presence of the SPD around the cabinet table will help German to focus more on eurozone growth. Speaking on France 2 TV shortly before Merkel was voted back in, Moscovici declared: It's true that the previous administration was far too focused on austerity.... Now there is a Social Democratic partner ... I think we'll have a Germany that is more growth-oriented. That could boost the spending power of poorer Germans. But the CDU baulked at the idea of raising taxes to fund additional government spending on infrastructure projects. The formalities are over - Angela Merkel is officially Germany's leader again. Over in Germany, Angela Merkel will be formally voted in as German chancellor this morning, for the third time, as the new coalition between her CDU/CSU party and the Social Democrats gets down to business. Although the CDU-SPD coalition is new, there's no change at the top of one key department. Diamond founded Atlas Mara with billionaire entrepreneur Ashish Thakkar, chief executive of Mara Group. Reuters has more details: The proceeds from the initial public offering included a $20 million investment by its founders. The vehicle will be managed by Atlas Merchant Capital, the merchant bank Diamond has set up in New York with a view to expand into sub-Saharah African banks and financial services. Economists and traders will be glued to their terminals in an hour's time when the latest UK inflation data, for November, flashes up. City analysts reckon there will be no change in the rising cost of living, with the Consumer Prices Index expected to rise by 2.2%, matching October. As economics reporter Katie Allen explains, that would mean real wages were still shrinking . The consumer price index measure of inflation is expected to hold at 2.2% in November according to the consensus forecast in a Reuters poll. But some economists see the rate dropping to 2% while others have pencilled in a rise to 2.5%. Inflation has been above average annual earnings growth for several years now and the latest official figures put pay growth at 0.8%. The big transport (and political) news in Britain today is that a government report into airport congestion has recommended building new runways at either Heathrow or Gatwick. The government-appointed independent commission, led by Sir Howard Davies has issued a shortlist of three options for building new runways in the south-east in its interim report. The options set out by Davies are: a third runway to the north of Heathrow, a second proposal for Heathrow expansion put forward by the Heathrow Hub group, and a new second runway to the south of Gatwick. Heathrow and Gatwick airports shortlisted for new runways So, no joy for 'Boris Island' -- instead, the prospect of even more flights over the capital, including its more salubrious 'burbs. It reckons that insurers of the driver who wasn't at fault in an accident are running up unnecessary charges (repairs, replacement cars and the like), meaning the 'at fault' driver's insurers pick up the bill. Ultimately, everyone suffers, with up to £200m of extra costs needing to be spread across premiums. As Alasdair Smith of the CC explains: There is insufficient incentive for insurers to keep costs down even though they are themselves on the receiving end of the problem. webTitle: Mark Carney stands by forward guidance policy

fields.standfirst: Bank of Englang governor denies approach on future interest rates is confusing for business or consumers
fields.body:
The Bank of England governor, Mark Carney, has robustly defended his forward guidance policy in parliament against critics who argue it is confusing and has done little to persuade markets that an interest rate rise can be delayed for three years while the economy mends.

Speaking to the House of Lords economics committee, Carney said businesses and consumers understood that forward guidance meant interest rates would stay low until unemployment falls to 7%, which the central bank predicts will happen in 2016.

Carney said: "A return to growth is not the same as a return to normality", and base rates should remain at the historically low 0.5% level until the recovery was established.

He spoke as the Office for National Statistics revealed that the consumer prices measure of inflation slowed to 2.1% in November from 2.2% in October and was at its lowest since November 2009. The move closer to the Bank of England's government-set target of 2% will give policymakers more leeway to leave interest rates at their record low.

Carney told the committee Britain's return to growth was sufficient to justify resisting calls to increase the quantitative easing (QE) stimulus programme, which Threadneedle Street has held steady for the last two years.

MPs have accused Carney of establishing a highly technical policy of forward guidance that relies on several caveats, or knockouts; this reliance has, they say, undermined the simplicity of the message. Forward guidance includes clauses that allow the bank to push up interest rates should it believe inflation is likely to increase sharply.

Markets have estimated that interest rates will need to rise in 2015 in response to a sustained increase in GDP and higher-than-expected inflation.

Carney said forward guidance had reassured households and businesses that credit would remain cheap until the economy was in better shape.

"Forward guidance is having an effect in the real economy. My experience, having met with more than 300 businesses around the country, is that business people understand forward guidance well. This is confirmed by the reports of our network of agents across the nation," he said.

"What matters most for households and businesses is not market expectations of interest rates, but what actually happens to bank rate now and in the future. That is because the interest rates on 70% of mortgage loans to households and more than 50% of loans to businesses are linked to bank rate."

Lord Lawson, the former Tory chancellor, said he was concerned that the central bank's QE programme to stimulate the economy would be maintained long after interest rates began to rise. He was responding to comments by Carney restating the bank's long-held policy that interest rates should increase before the sale of assets under the QE programme.

Lawson, who wants the bank to start selling the QE programme's £375bn of government bonds, said there was disquiet about the long-term effects of QE, which had artificially forced down the interest rate on government debt.

Carney said interest rates would need to rise to cool the economy ahead of a sale of government bonds.

webTitle: Published version of RBS report was edited, business department admits

fields.standfirst: Vince Cable's department says full version of document alleging bank forced small business to close was sent to watchdogs
fields.body:
Vince Cable's business department has admitted that the scathing report into Royal Bank of Scotland's treatment of small business customers published last month was different to the one the business secretary had received.

The report, which alleges the bailed-out bank had deliberately forced small firms to go bust to enable RBS to make bigger profits, has prompted the City regulator to investigate and has aroused the interest of the Serious Fraud Office.

The business department said the report Cable saw, by his entrepreneur-in-residence Lawrence Tomlinson, had been sent in full to the Financial Conduct Authority and Prudential Regulation Authority, but the version Tomlinson published last month had been "edited" and "amended".

In the 20-page executive summary, published at the end of November, Tomlinson cites evidence from businesses that ended up in RBS's global restructuring group (GRG) and subsequently had their properties sold to its specialist property arm, West Register.

He does not provide the identities of individuals who have complained, and has faced some scrutiny for removing references to Lloyds Banking Group from an earlier version of his report.

In response to written questions by the shadow business secretary, Chuka Umunna, the business department admitted changes had been made – though not, it said, at the behest of ministers.

Responding on behalf of the department, the Conservative MP Matthew Hancock said in a written answer: "Mr Tomlinson's report on the bank's treatment of businesses in distress was sent to the department for business, innovation and skills (BIS) and seen by ministers, special advisers and officials. The report was passed on in full without amendment to the Financial Conduct Authority and the Prudential Regulation Authority for them to consider.

"Mr Tomlinson subsequently decided to publish an edited and amended version of the report. The editorial decisions were made by Mr Tomlinson, who published the report in an individual capacity. The report was not a matter for approval by anyone within BIS," Hancock said.

Tomlinson has previously told the Guardian the vast majority of complaints he received – and turned into case studies for his report – were about RBS and its GRG operation.

"Roughly, in the first report, cases that we distilled down, 20 were RBS and two were Lloyds and one was something else; or it was 20 and three, or something like that," he said.

Tomlinson is based in Leeds and runs a business that builds sports and racing cars and runs and builds care homes.

Lloyds said: "Tomlinson came to us and the examples weren't SMEs and, when we looked, no evidence of any wrongdoing [was found] so he took them out."

webTitle: National Express accelerates, but Sainsbury slides as discounters take market share

fields.standfirst: Transport groups, supermarkets and insurers in focus as markets await Federal Reserve
fields.body:
In a market once again stuck in the slow lane, a number of transport companies went full steam ahead.

National Express added 1.8p to 264.5p after the bus and train company said it was on track to meet full year profit expectations for around £143m after positive fourth quarter trading. Coach revenue was expected to see a 9% increase in the final three months of the year, with its bus and rail businesses also moving ahead. It is currently bidding on £10bn worth of contracts, with three UK rail tenders expected to be submitted in the next four months. John Lawson at Investec said:

National Express has delivered a solid message with revenue growth across all of the businesses. Management has a strong focus on cash generation and capital discipline and this is being reflected in its financial performance, with around £150m of free cash per annum now being generated. Whilst we keep our hold and 250p target price for now, the trends are improving.

Meanwhile, in a note on the sector, Goldman Sachs put a neutral rating on the business. But the bank raised its recommendation on Go-Ahead, up 52p to £17.04, from neutral to buy with a target price lifted from £15.80 to £21.

But FirstGroup, whose commuter links into London were once more in chaos, dipped 0.8p to 118.5p despite Goldman edging its target price 5p higher to 140p.

Stagecoach slid 4.6p to 365p as the bank put a sell rating on the business.

Overall, the FTSE 100 fell 36.01 points to 6486.19. The US Federal Reserve was still uppermost in investors' minds as its last meeting of the year began. There is still a slight chance the Fed might announce an easing of its $85bn monthly bond buying programme, given recent positive US economic data, and this prospect continued to unsettle the market. Alastair McCaig, market analyst at IG, said:

In the run up [to the Fed meeting] 34% of institutional analysts are predicting a cut to the monthly debt purchasing scheme; though this of course still means that 66% think there will be none. Clearly the majority held sway on Monday as markets rallied, but, 24 hours before the meeting itself, nerves have crept back in as equity indices have fallen.

Retailers were in the spotlight. Shares in the major supermarkets came under pressure as new figures showed them continuing to lose market share to the discounters.

For the first time more than half of Britain's households shopped in Aldi or Lidl, according to Kantar Worldpanel's grocery share data for the 12 weeks to 8 December. The news sent J Sainsbury shares down 16.9p to 378.6p, Tesco 6.5p lower to 324.5p, and Morrisons off 7.7p to 256.7p.

Elsewhere Dixons Retail dropped 2.57p to 48.73p on profit taking after better than expected first half results. Six month profits jumped from £14m to £30.2m, higher than forecasts of up to £26m, after strong sales of tablet computers. But the company was cautious on the outlook, saying the second half would be more challenging, not least because the benefit of rival Comet's demise would no longer be reflected in the figures.

RSA Insurance, under pressure since Friday's profit warning and the departure of its chief executive, rebounded despite Standard & Poor's cutting its credit rating from A to A- and Fitch putting it on negative watch.

Bargain hunters appeared to have moved in since last week's slump, and its shares added 2.3p to 92.4p, the biggest riser in the FTSE 100.

Heading the other way was Admiral, down 28p at £12.33 after the competition commission said car insurance premiums were too high. Esure ended 7p lower at 240p while Direct Line dipped 1.7p to 230.9p.

A warning from French oil industry surveying firm CGG sent the oil services sector lower, with Petrofac down 43p at £11.10.

Among the mid-caps, Cable & Wireless Communications continued to climb after Monday's speculation of a possible US bid, up another 1.8p to 50.80p.

Lower down the market, Aim-listed cloud computing group Nasstar dropped 3.75p to 6.75p after it unveiled a reverse takeover by Denara Holdings, which owns hosted desktop and managed services business e-know.net. Nasstar is paying £13m, made up of £9m in cash and £4m in shares. To fund the deal and provided additional working capital, the company has conditionally raised £10.5m by issuing shares at 5p each.

Finally Blur Group, which operates an online marketplace for companies to buy and sell services, added 2.5p to 452.5p after it reported that more than 2000 projects had been submitted to its Global Services Exchange in 2013, a tenfold increase on 2010.

webTitle: Network Rail to be 'government body', adding £30bn to UK national debt

fields.bodyText: Network Rail will be reclassified as a government body in 2014 as part of a package of changes to the public finances, adding £30bn to Britain's national debt, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) has announced. Because the government plays a significant role in overseeing Network Rail, through the Office of the Rail Regulator, and the taxpayer would inevitably be left picking up the bill for keeping the trains running if Network Rail collapsed, the ONS says it is best considered a "central government body". That will bump up public sector net debt for 2012-13 by approximately £30bn, or 2% of GDP, when the change is implemented next year – and will fuel the debate about the size of the public subsidy for the railway network. Transport secretary Patrick McLoughlin said in a statement: "The government welcomes the ONS review and has always been committed to the transparent reporting of public liabilities." He added: "I am committed to ensuring that Network Rail maintains the operational flexibility to continue to deliver a safe, punctual rail network and increased capacity for our busy railways and that it is able to attract a high calibre of staff, while still providing value for money and being accountable to Parliament". The announcement came as part of an ONS consultation on plans to implement pan-European standards on calculating taxation, public spending and debt, known as ESA10. webTitle: London airport expansion: the Davies commission shortlist

fields.standfirst: Options for increasing air capacity at Heathrow and Gatwick but Thames Estuary 'Boris Island' airport still under consideration
fields.body:
The Davies shortlist options:

Gatwick: a second runway

A 3km runway to the south, costing around £10-13bn, far enough from the existing runway to be operated independently and so able to expand capacity dramatically. Around 200 homes would be lost. Has far fewer planning difficulties so a potentially easier option.

Heathrow: an additional northwest runway

The airport's preferred option: a 3.5km runway which for Heathrow is much better than the shorter runway approved under Labour then scrapped in 2010. The proposal will mean the demolition of the village of Harmondsworth and the building of a new Terminal 6. Costs estimated at around £17bn. The airport claims it will mean fewer people severely impacted by noise, although people in Chiswick and Ealing would be under new flight paths. Would provide an additional 260,000 flights a year.

Heathrow: the Heathrow Hub plan

A proposal from a group that owns options on land to the north, the core idea is extending the existing northern runway westward to 6km to effectively operate as two separate runways for landing and take off. It would increase noise overall, and significantly affect local respite periods, but reduce night noise. Only 720 properties would be demolished. The idea also could provide more integrated transport links with rail including HS2, although Davies said that this aspect was attractive but not the focus of the plan. Would provide 190,000 extra flights a year.

And the one not on the shortlist:

Thames Estuary: Isle of Grain

The various options proposed around the estuary – including the original offshore "Boris Island" proposal – have been condensed by Davies to one, "the most viable" of schemes that the commission describes as "presenting many challenges and uncertainties". It could possibly be shortlisted after further study in 2014. The Isle of Grain proposal, one made by architect Norman Foster, would have four runways and would have a high-speed rail link to London. The cost would be, according to the commission's interim report, up to £112bn.

webTitle: Debenhams demands supplier discount eight days before Christmas

fields.bodyText: Debenhams has demanded that its suppliers pay a 2.5% a discount on goods just eight days before Christmas. The high street retailer told suppliers last night that it will take the money from their accounts on Tuesday. Suppliers had not been consulted about the discount demand in advance. Simon Herrick, Debenhams' finance director, told suppliers: "As we will mutually benefit from the growth of Debenhams we are now seeking a contribution from our suppliers to support our commitment to on-going investment." Herrick did not explain why suppliers must pay the money just before Christmas – a notoriously tricky time of the year for both retailers and suppliers. A spokeswoman for Debenhams said the timing of the demand "lands when it lands", and said it was "not to do with Christmas necessarily". The spokesman declined to comment on whether Debenhams was suffering from cash-flow difficulties. In the letter emailed to own-brand suppliers on Monday night, Herrick said they had to help contribute to Debenhams' expansion and refurbishment plans. The modernisation programme, which includes a £25bn facelift for the Oxford Street branch, has yet to improve the chain's financial performance. The company reported a 2.7% fall in pre-tax profits to £154m in the year to the end of August. Debenhams, which is also planning to open 14 new stores over the next four years, said the discount demand was not unusual in the retail industry and pointed out that both John Lewis and Laura Ashley have asked for supplier discounts. However these discounts were demanded in March not the week before Christmas. Retail analyst Richard Hyman, a consultant at Verdict Research, said: "Screwing your suppliers is something that is easy to do but the implications of that are something quite far reaching. "It is very important for retailers to look after their partners as well as their customers. The pain and the benefit have to be shared out with a reasonable degree of democracy." Debenhams shares were down 3% in afternoon trading. • This article was amended on 18 December 2013 because Debenhams spent £25m on a facelift for its Oxford Street branch, not £25bn as the original said.

webTitle: George Osborne winning political battle over austerity – but not economic one | Larry Elliott

fields.standfirst: YouGov poll shows more people say spending cuts are good rather than bad for the economy
fields.body:
George Osborne is winning the political battle over austerity. That's the conclusion from the latest YouGov poll showing that for the first time since late 2010 more people say spending cuts are good rather than bad for the economy.

Let's be clear. The poll does not mean it made economic sense for the chancellor to take the axe to Whitehall departments and to the welfare bill. Academic studies suggest that the level of activity in the UK would already be above its pre-recession peak rather than 2% or so below it had it not been for the spending cuts and tax increases brought in by Osborne.

The recovery has been a long time in coming and has been the weakest of any country in the G7 bar Italy. What's more, the continued weakness of business investment calls into question the main thrust of Osborne's case: that reducing the budget deficit would boost confidence and make the private sector more confident about expanding capacity.

Politically, though, it is a different story. What has happened since the election is as follows. Back in the early days of the coalition the public said it was up for a bit of belt-tightening but the enthusiasm did not last long.

By the end of 2010, when austerity was starting to bite, the mood had changed and throughout 2011 and 2012 – the years when the economy flat-lined – the public was solidly against the cuts. In the summer of 2012 there was a 20-point gap between those who thought cuts were harming Britain and those who thought they were helping.

Since then, though, the gap has been closing and in the latest YouGov study the lines have again crossed as the return to growth has made the cuts much less politically toxic. The chancellor will see the findings both as a vindication of his handling of the nation's finances and as evidence that the public does not have austerity fatigue. That's just as well given that the Treasury has plans to carry on cutting spending for another five years.

Conversely, the YouGov findings represent a warning to Labour. It would appear that the public bought the argument that austerity would put the brake on growth (as it did) only for as long as the economy was struggling. Voters seem unimpressed with the opposition's current line: that recovery would have happened sooner without the cuts and that the cost of "two wasted years" has been a much higher deficit than was planned back in 2010.

One crumb of comfort for Labour is that while the public is now much less hostile to the cuts, it is still unimpressed with the way the government is running the economy. Just over a third (36%) say the coalition is handling things well, against 54% who say they are managing them badly, with little change in this balance over the past six months.

This may have a lot to do with the nature of the recovery, which is showing up in the data for gross domestic product but not in pay packets. The public will only really believe Osborne's narrative – that cuts were unavoidable and helped to build confidence in the UK – when it translates into rising living standards. Even with inflation coming down, this is unlikely to occur until the second half of 2014.

webTitle: CBI survey of manufacturers' order books at 18-year high

fields.standfirst: Survey follows other reports from the manufacturing sector suggesting it is picking up steam after a deep recession
fields.body:
Britain's manufacturers ramped up production in December to keep up with rising demand, according to a survey that put their assessment of order books at an 18-year high.

The Confederation of British Industry (CBI) said its poll of the sector also showed a pickup in export orders, driven by demand for chemicals and cars.

In the survey, 35% of firms reported that their total orders were above normal in December and 23% said they were below; that difference, of 12%, was the biggest since February 1995.

Growth in output volumes over the three months to December had remained robust and was broad-based, the CBI said. Fourteen out of 16 sectors reported growth, with motor vehicles and transport equipment the largest contributors.

Manufacturers expected output growth to continue over the coming three months, albeit at a somewhat slower pace, the survey indicated.

"While risks remain in the eurozone and beyond, this survey provides further evidence that the recovery is becoming more embedded," said Stephen Gifford, the CBI's director of economics.

Economists said the survey fanned hopes that the sector, which accounts for 10% of the UK economy, helped boost overall growth in the final quarter of this year.

Howard Archer, chief UK and European economist at IHS Global Insight, detected "very good news on the manufacturing front, with a robust CBI industrial trends survey for December indicating that the sector enjoyed a strong fourth quarter and is very well placed going into 2014 with domestic and export orders elevated".

The survey follows other reports from the manufacturing sector suggesting it is picking up steam after a deep recession. Output from the sector is, however, still well below its pre-crisis level, and the latest official data showed exports falling.

webTitle: Dixons hails black Friday as the new Easter for electrical retailers

fields.bodyText: Black Friday could next year overtake Easter to become UK electricals retailers' third most important sales day after Christmas and Boxing Day, according to the Dixons boss, Seb James. James said the US-inspired discount day, which falls on the first weekend in December, had been Dixons' fourth most successful trading day of the year, and would kick off the Christmas rush in future. "I think it is really going to become part of the UK retail market for everyone," he said. He said the idea was good for a large retailer such as Dixons, as it could plan with manufacturers to offer big deals on items such as TVs by placing special large orders that preserved profit margins. "It definitely pulls forward and then pushes back sales, but you can make money," James said. There was a risk, however, that the discount day could leave shoppers expecting deals all through the runup to Christmas, retailers' busiest trading period of the year, he warned. Dixons said the popularity of the BBC television series The Great British Bake Off was boosting sales of kitchen gadgets in the runup to Christmas but warned of a challenging period ahead. James said baking-related products of all kinds were flying off the shelves, with Kitchenaid mixers in "garish colours" proving particularly popular. The group behind Currys and PC World reported a first-half underlying pre-tax profit of £30.2m in the six months to 31 October, up from £14m in the same period last year. Like-for-like sales – those stripping out the impact of stores which have been open for less than a year – increased by 6% over the period. The UK and Ireland business performed particularly well, with like-for-like sales up 9%, and sales were up 3% on the same measure in northern Europe. The group said like-for-like sales in Greece were down 14% in the first half, however, as the economic storm persisted and as a much cooler summer this year hit sales of air conditioning units, which boomed a year earlier amid a heatwave. "Our Greek business continues to grow market share against some gusty headwinds," James said. Total group sales rose to £3.43bn from £3.2bn. Sales were boosted by demand for the iPad Air tablet and large televisions, as well as by baking products. Boxing Day marks the beginning of the biggest week of trading for the Dixons group. James warned, however, that the second half of the year was likely to prove more challenging overall amid a weak consumer backdrop and as the benefits reaped after the collapse of the rival company Comet at the end of 2012 made for a difficult comparative period. "We are cautious as there are headwinds in many of our markets. The macro economy is still quiet, especially for discretionary spending like this," he said.

webTitle: Big four supermarkets continue to lose market share to discounters

fields.standfirst: For the first time more than half UK households decide to shop at Aldi and Lidl
fields.body:
Supermarket shares have come under pressure as new figures show them continuing to lose market share to the discounters.

For the first time more than half of Britain's households shopped in Aldi or Lidl, according to Kantar Worldpanel's grocery share data for the 12 weeks to 8 December. Some 50.1% shopped in a discount retailer compared with 46.1% a year ago. Chris Longbottom, director at Kantar Worldpanel, said:

Aldi now boasts a record 4.0% of the grocery market having increased its share for nearly every 12-week period since the end of 2010. Lidl retains its record share of 3.1% which it reached during the summer.

The news has sent J Sainsbury shares down 10.2p to 385.3p, Tesco 4.25p lower to 326.75p, and Morrisons off 2.5p to 261.9. The other big four supermarket, Asda, is owned by Wal-Mart.

Over the period the overall grocery market grew by 2.8% while Sainsbury was up 1.8%, Tesco 0.4%, Asda 0.6% and Morrisons 0.8%.

webTitle: Talvivaara jumps 27% as Finnish miner wins approval for debt restructuring

fields.standfirst: Struggling nickel group gets court go-ahead for reorganisation and restarts production
fields.body:
Finnish nickel miner Talvivaara Mining Company has stepped back from the brink, after court approval for a restructuring.

The company has been hit by falling nickel prices and its own severe production problems, and ran into financial difficulties as a result, to the point where it was threatened with bankruptcy. But a court decision to allow it to reorganise its debt and news that production restarted last week have lifted its shares up 27% to 8.75p. They are still down around 70% over the past two years, however.

Chief executive Pekka Pera said:

With the reorganisation process now beginning, we can also continue our metals production, which re-commenced last week after a one month stoppage of our metals recovery plant.

webTitle: UK inflation falls to four-year low of 2.1% as food prices steady

fields.standfirst: Move closer to Bank of England's 2% target gives policymakers more headroom to leave interest rates at record low
fields.body:
Inflation has fallen back to its slowest pace in four years thanks to steadying food prices and the fact that energy price hikes have yet to come in.

The consumer prices measure of inflation slowed to 2.1% in November from 2.2% in October and was the lowest since November 2009, according to the Office for National Statistics. The move closer to the Bank of England's government-set target of 2% will give policymakers more headroom to leave interest rates at their record low. It will also ease the pressure on households that have been grappling with living costs rising at a faster pace than average wages for several years.

"The fall in UK CPI inflation from 2.2% to 2.1% in November confirms that the economy is enjoying a favourable mix of strong growth and low inflation," said Samuel Tombs at the thinktank Capital Economics.

"We continue to think that CPI inflation is likely to dip below the 2% target in 2014. As a result, even if earnings growth recovers only marginally next year, an end to the squeeze on real earnings is finally in sight."

November's inflation was just below forecasts for 2.2% in a Reuters poll of economists and the monthly rise in prices of 0.1% was below forecasts for 0.2%.

webTitle: Bob Diamond could gain millions from new African investment venture

fields.bodyText: Bob Diamond, ousted as boss of Barclays last year after the Libor-rigging scandal, potentially stands to reap millions of pounds from a new stock market venture set up to acquire financial services companies in Africa. The US banker, often criticised for the level of his pay during his 15 years at Barclays, has become a nonexecutive director of a cash shell that has raised £200m from a stock market listing in London, although registered in the British Virgin Islands. Along with his co-founder, Ashish Thakkar – a British national now based in Dubai – Diamond has special "founder-preferred shares" in the new vehicle, known as Atlas Mara Co-Nvest, which give the pair payouts if the share price rises above a certain level. Atlas Mara Co-Nvest is based on Diamond's New York firm Atlas Merchant Capital and Thakkar's Mara range of businesses in 19 African countries. The two companies have invested $20m in the cash shell. Thakkar, often described as Africa's youngest billionaire, started his first IT companies in 1995 at the age of 15 in Uganda and is one of the World Economic Forum's young global leaders. In a stock market announcement, Atlas Mara Co-Nvest said that although it was not involved in any discussions with target companies it could make acquisitions anywhere in the world, and was likely to pick Africa. To counter concerns that shell companies often tie up investors' cash without making deals, the business will be wound up in 12 months if no deals have been concluded by then. Arnold Ekpe, a former boss of Africa's Ecobank, has been appointed chairman of the company, on an annual fee of $125,000. The company has also named a number of non-executive directors, including Rachel Robbins, a former vice-president of the International Finance Corporation, who will get $85,000 a year. Ekpe is also receiving 50,000 five-year options over the shares, which listed at $10, and the non-executive directors are getting 37,500. Neither Diamond nor Thakkar is receiving any options or fees. The prospectus shows a higher fee, of $500,000, will go to Jyrki Koskelo, a former executive of the World Bank who will advise on potential acquisitions. The founder-preferred shares give a payout if the shares rise above $11.50 for 10 consecutive days after an acquisition. The payout is based on 20% of the difference between $11.50 and the share price. The 133-page prospectus said that while Barclays could face litigation over Libor fixing, Atlas Mara Co-Nvest does not believe it will have "an adverse impact on the company or its ability to make the acquisition (or subsequent acquisitions) or on MrDiamond's ability to perform his role for the company".

webTitle: RSA rebounds after recent losses, but Admiral and Esure hit by car premium news

fields.standfirst: Bargain hunters move in to snap up RSA shares, as investors await Fed meeting
fields.body:
The start of the two day US Federal Reserve meeting is at the back of investors minds, but in the spotlight at the moment is the insurance sector.

RSA Insurance, under pressure since Friday's profit warning and the departure of its chief executive, has rebounded despite Standard & Poor's cutting its credit rating from A to A- and Fitch putting it on negative watch.

But bargain hunters appear to have moved in since last week's slump, and its shares are up 2.15p to 92.25p, the biggest riser in the FTSE 100. Numis cut its price target by 15p to 85p, with a hold rating:

We remain cautious on RSA shares given near-term uncertainties, namely credit rating action, the outcome of the PwC review (expected in January 2014), details of the capital plan (expected before the finals in February 2014) and potential for new weather losses to put further pressure on the capital position. A weak hold at these levels.

Morgan Stanley said:

We expect the situation at RSA to be a volatile one near term as the group works to repair its solvency position. We remain overweight the stock, but flag this as one that carries higher than usual risk.

But Barclays remained negative:

RSA suffered two credit rating moves yesterday with the language in the rating agency notes pointing to weaker absolute capital positions, as well as hinting at some urgency to resolve the capital shortfall.We remain Underweight, with clarity urgently required over the plans to strengthen the solvency and assurance provided over the group reserve position.

Heading the other way was Admiral, 27p lower at £12.34 after the competition commission said car insurance premiums were too high. Esure is 7.1p lower at 239.9p while Direct Line is down 0.7p at 231.9p. Eamonn Flanagan at Shore Capital said:

To us, this all makes enormous sense, with the clear intention to drive a better deal for consumers, whether it be through lower prices and/or better information. We believe that the focus on add-ons (ie ancillary income) and price comparison websites is particularly negative for Admiral. However, the former is also negative for both Direct Line and Esure. The regulatory fog surrounding the UK personal motor insurance industry remains impenetrable, in our view…a sub-sector to steer well clear of.

A warning from French oil industry surveying firm CGG sent the oil services sector lower, with Petrofac down 30p at £11.23.

Elsewhere Dixons Retail has dropped 1.31p to 49.99p on profit taking after better than expected first half results. Six month profits jumped from £14m to £30.2m, higher than forecasts of up to £26m, after strong sales of tablet computers. But the company was cautious on the outlook, saying the second half would be more challenging, not least because the benefit of rival Comet's demise would no longer be reflected in the figures.

Cable & Wireless Communications continued to climb after Monday's speculation of a possible US bid, up another 1.65p to 50.65p.

Overall, ahead of tomorrow's Fed meeting when there must still be an outside chance the central bank will begin trimming its $85bn a month bond buying programme, the FTSE 100 has fallen 30 points to 6492.20, despite UK inflation falling to a four-year low. On the Fed, Ishaq Siddiqi at ETX Capital said:

Expectations of tapering continue to underpin price-action but most market participants believe the Fed will wait until early next year before starting the process as the US economy needs to shower greater momentum. Labour market indicators in recent weeks have been stronger, fuelling expectations the Fed will cut, combined with the recent two-year budget deal that was agreed last week by the House which will prevent a government shutdown next year. That being said, lawmakers still have to address raising the debt ceiling in February. This could be a potential reason for the Fed to hold back until more clarity.

webTitle: Born after 1960? Then you're probably poorer than your parents

fields.bodyText: The political row over falling living standards was stoked on Tuesday as it emerged that earnings-squeezed and pension-poor Britons born in the 1960s and 70s need inherited wealth to be better off in retirement than people born in earlier decades. After an autumn in which the cost of living has dominated Westminster debate, the Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) said its research showed the days when each generation could expect to be better off than their predecessors might be ending. The in-depth survey of people born between the Battle of Britain in 1940 and the arrival of Margaret Thatcher in Downing Street in 1979 found that a decade in which real incomes have stagnated – coupled with changes to pensions and high house prices – has made life tougher for people currently in their 30s, 40s and early 50s than those born earlier. The IFS said living standards for those currently considered to be in the prime of their working lives were now dependent on wealth passed down the generations, and that this was heavily skewed towards the already better-off. Andrew Hood, a research economist at IFS and an author of the report, said: "Since the second world war, successive cohorts have enjoyed higher incomes and living standards than their parents. Yet the incomes and wealth of those born in the 1960s and 70s look no higher than the cohorts who came before them. As a result, younger cohorts are likely to have to rely on inheritances to be better off in retirement than their predecessors." Hood said the IFS had not yet studied what sort of retirement might be expected by those born in the 80s and 90s, but there was nothing to suggest the outlook had improved. The main findings of the IFS report were: • Since the war, steady growth has meant each generation had higher incomes and living standards than the one before. • Those born in the 60s and 70s are less likely to own a home. • The trend stalled in the past decade, with individuals born in the 60s and 70s having the same take-home pay as workers born a decade earlier. • The children of the 60s and 70s had higher incomes during early adulthood than their predecessors but spent the extra. • Compared with those born in the 40s and 50s, they are likely to have smaller private pension pots and will find that the state pension replaces a smaller slice of their earnings prior to retirement. The IFS said: "The main conclusion is that individuals born in the 60s and 70s are likely to be reliant on inherited wealth if they are to be any better off in retirement than their predecessors. Many more people in younger cohorts expect to inherit wealth; but expected inheritances are distributed unequally and are higher for those who are already wealthier. The results suggest that the rapid improvement in economic outcomes across birth cohorts that we have seen in recent decades may be coming to a halt." In recent weeks, political parties have traded blows over the cost of living, with Ed Miliband making it the focus of his attack on the government. George Osborne last week said Britain was poorer because of the financial and economic crisis of 2007-09, when Labour was in power. A government spokesman said: "The only way to raise living standards is to raise productivity by continuing to implement the economic plan that has got the economy growing, created 1.4 million new private sector jobs and cut the deficit by a third. "As part of this plan, we are committed to protecting pensioners, who have worked hard all their lives, to ensure their dignity in retirement. "In addition to introducing the triple lock on the basic state pension, we have also protected a number of pensioner benefits – for instance, free bus passes and TV licences. We are reforming the UK's state pension system to be more sustainable for the future and widening access to a workplace pension. These combined reforms will improve the incomes of 9 million people currently facing inadequate income in retirement." But Angus Hanton of the Intergenerational Foundation said: "This report shows rapidly growing intergenerational imbalances where younger generations face soaring costs of housing and education while receiving lower earnings and pensions, contrasting with the relative prosperity of older generations. "Policymakers should not equate old age with need. They are protecting older, wealthier generations while stripping benefits from families and young people." The thinktank said many of the factors adversely affecting those born in the 60s and 70s were the "straightforward consequences" of recent trends. After strong growth in the 80s and 90s, real incomes are no higher now than they were a decade ago and were growing only weakly even before the financial crash. Over the same period, companies have made a rapid switch from final salary pension schemes to less generous defined contribution schemes in which younger workers have been accumulating less private pension wealth. "Policy changes – themselves often driven by the inevitable fiscal pressures associated with an ageing society – explain the key changes across cohorts in state pension entitlements." The IFS said more research needed to be done into why those born in the 60s and 70s "spent all, and saved none, of the additional income that they had in young adulthood relative to their predecessors". "Inheritances look like the major potential reason why the later economic position of cohorts born in the 60s and 70s could yet turn out better than that of their predecessors, on average. Only 28% of individuals born in the early 40s could expect an inheritance, but that rose to 70% for people born in the 70s. The study found that of those born in 1972-78, 78% of the wealthiest third and 45% of the poorest third expected a future inheritance, while 35% of the wealthiest third and 12% of the poorest third expected a future inheritance worth at least £100,000. "Expected future inheritances also tend to be concentrated within the same households: individuals expecting inheritances are far more likely to have partners who also expect them. "In combination with the lack of positive signs with respect to other economic indicators, this suggests that the economic fate of the 60s and 70s generations may be relatively dependent on the fortunes of their parents. But the prevalence and value of expected future inheritances are distributed unequally, with households that are already relatively wealthy far more likely to benefit." The IFS said that during their early adulthood, those born in the 60s and 70s enjoyed much higher take-home incomes than previous generations at a similar age. At 30, the real median income for someone born in the 70s was 20% higher than someone born in the 60s, 52% higher than that of someone born in the 50s and 77% higher than for someone born in the 40s. "These income differences between birth cohorts at younger ages were (at least) matched by differences in spending", the IFS said. "As a result, the 1960s and 1970s cohorts had higher living standards during early adulthood than their predecessors had, but they have not actively saved more take-home income than their predecessors had by the same stage in life."

webTitle: Job optimism at highest level since recession, survey suggests

fields.standfirst: But squeeze on living standards and skills gap may continue to cause problems
fields.body:
A new survey on job prospects in the UK shows that companies are at their most optimistic about hiring new workers since the onset of recession. But the squeeze on living standards will continue, with most employers in the CBI's poll remaining cautious about increasing pay – only 7% intend to raise salaries by more than inflation.

The business lobby group's annual employment survey showed that more companies expected to create jobs than not in the next 12 months. It also pointed to a brighter outlook for graduates and a pick-up in apprenticeship schemes and said the rise in permanent jobs was outstripping growth in temporary jobs.

But the report, with consultants Accenture, also highlighted firms' worries about filling skilled roles, particularly in science, engineering and construction. "We're starting to see the recovery have an impact on business plans to hire, with more than half of firms boosting staff numbers next year and more opportunities for young people," said Katja Hall, CBI chief policy director.
